name: methylseq-dna-methylation
title: Bisulfite-seq DNA Methylation Profiling
description: Genome-wide DNA methylation analysis using bisulfite sequencing. Maps cytosine methylation at single-base resolution for epigenetic studies. Samplesheet format: `sample,fastq_1,fastq_2`
content:
Bisulfite-seq DNA Methylation

DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification where methyl groups are added to cytosines (5mC), primarily in CpG dinucleotides. Bisulfite sequencing is the gold standard for genome-wide methylation mapping at single-base resolution.

What is Bisulfite Sequencing?

The Technique:

  1. Bisulfite Conversion: Unmethylated cytosines (C) → uracil (U)
  2. Methylated Cytosines Protected: 5-methylcytosine (5mC) remains as C
  3. PCR Amplification: Uracils become thymines (T)
  4. Sequencing: Compare to reference genome
  5. Analysis: C in read = methylated, T in read = unmethylated

Types of Bisulfite Sequencing

WGBS (Whole Genome Bisulfite Sequencing):

  • Complete methylome at single-base resolution
  • 30-50X coverage needed
  • Expensive but comprehensive
  • ~28 million CpG sites in human genome

RRBS (Reduced Representation Bisulfite Sequencing):

  • Enriches for CpG-rich regions (MspI digestion)
  • Covers ~10% of CpGs but includes promoters/CpG islands
  • More affordable, lower coverage needs
  • Good for differential methylation studies

Targeted BS-seq:

  • Specific regions (promoters, candidate genes)
  • Capture-based or PCR amplification
  • Deep coverage of selected regions

Why Study DNA Methylation?

  • Gene Silencing: Promoter methylation → transcriptional repression
  • Imprinting: Parent-of-origin gene expression
  • X-Inactivation: Female mammals silence one X chromosome
  • Development: Methylation patterns change during differentiation
  • Cancer: Hypermethylation silences tumor suppressors
  • Aging: Epigenetic clock based on methylation changes
  • Disease: Aberrant methylation in neurodegeneration, metabolic disorders

CpG Islands and Shores

CpG Islands:

  • CG-rich regions (>500bp, >55% GC, Obs/Exp CpG >0.65)
  • ~70% at gene promoters
  • Usually unmethylated in normal cells
  • Hypermethylation in cancer → gene silencing

CpG Shores:

  • ±2kb flanking CpG islands
  • Differential methylation often occurs here
  • Associated with gene expression changes

CpG Shelves:

  • ±2-4kb from CpG islands
  • Tissue-specific methylation

Methylation Patterns

Hypomethylated Regions:

  • Active promoters: Transcriptionally active genes
  • CpG islands: Default unmethylated state
  • Enhancers: Active regulatory elements

Hypermethylated Regions:

  • Gene bodies: Paradoxically associated with transcription
  • Repetitive elements: Transposon silencing
  • Imprinted loci: Parental allele-specific
  • Inactive X chromosome: Female X-inactivation
  • Cancer genes: Tumor suppressor silencing

Pipeline Analysis

  1. Quality Control: FastQC, trim adapters
  2. Bisulfite Alignment: Bismark (or bwa-meth) maps converted reads
  3. Deduplication: Remove PCR duplicates
  4. Methylation Extraction: Call methylation at each CpG
  5. M-bias Correction: Remove end-repair bias
  6. CpG Context Analysis: Classify CpGs (islands, shores, shelves)
  7. Differential Methylation: DMRs (differentially methylated regions)
  8. Annotation: Genes/promoters with altered methylation

Aligners

Bismark (default):

  • Gold standard for bisulfite sequencing
  • Handles both directional and non-directional libraries
  • Comprehensive methylation calling

bwa-meth:

  • Faster alignment
  • Uses BWA-MEM algorithm
  • Good for large WGBS datasets

Scientific Questions

  • Developmental Methylation: How does methylation change during differentiation?
  • Cancer Epigenetics: Which tumor suppressors are hypermethylated?
  • Aging Clock: Can we predict biological age from methylation?
  • Environmental Effects: Does diet/stress alter methylation?
  • Imprinting Disorders: Abnormal parental allele methylation
  • Cell Identity: Tissue-specific methylation patterns

Applications

  • Cancer: Hypermethylation of BRCA1, VHL, MLH1 in tumors
  • Aging: Horvath clock (353 CpGs predict age)
  • Stem Cells: Reprogramming erases methylation
  • Neuroscience: Activity-dependent methylation, learning & memory
  • Imprinting Disorders: Beckwith-Wiedemann, Angelman syndromes
  • Pharmacology: DNMT inhibitors (5-azacytidine) reactivate silenced genes

Key Metrics

  • Bisulfite Conversion Rate: Should be >99% (check unmethylated spike-in control)
  • CpG Coverage: Number of CpGs with ≥10X coverage
  • Global Methylation: % methylated CpGs genome-wide
  • Duplication Rate: PCR duplicates (higher in RRBS)

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • sample: Sample name
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ (for paired-end)

Key Outputs

  • Methylation Calls: Per-CpG methylation levels (bedGraph, BigWig)
  • CpG Coverage: Number of reads per CpG
  • Differential Methylation: DMRs between conditions
  • M-bias Plots: QC for end-repair artifacts
  • Bisulfite Conversion Report: Conversion efficiency
  • Methylation Context: CpG islands, shores, shelves
  • Gene Annotation: Methylated promoters, gene bodies
  • QC Report: MultiQC summary

Perfect for: DNA methylation • Epigenetics • Cancer • Aging • Development • Gene silencing • Imprinting
